Focusing on the Fertile Crescent region (approximately 600,000 km2) between 8000 and 2000 years before present, this project will employ a hybrid research approach, combining archaeological settlement data and archaeobotanical data with General Circulation Models to reconstruct the complex relationships between climate, landscape, and society.

By applying cutting-edge techniques in archaeological data science and big data analysis, we will construct empirical datasets to examine population densities, distribution, subsistence practices, and landscape management strategies in response to abrupt and longer-term climate changes. Our research goal is to provide new insights into the sustainability and resilience of societies in the face of environmental stressors.

The CLaSS project has significant implications for understanding the dynamics of human-environment interaction and the consequences of climate change for societal stability. By exploring the successes and failures of ancient societies, we can inform strategies for building resilient and sustainable communities in the face of contemporary climate challenges. Ultimately, this project aims to contribute to a deeper understanding of the intricate relationships between climate, landscape, and society, shedding light on the complex factors that have shaped human history.
